Award.AbstractNarration:
Newer faculty often find the process of writing their first grant proposals to be quite challenging. Professors Malika Jeffries-EL of Boston University and Jeffrey Moore of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign are organizing a workshop that seeks to clarify that proposal writing and reviewing processes and position newer faculty to write more competitive proposals to federal funding agencies. Participants have the opportunity to network with successful grant recipients and program officers. They engage in mock panels, speed coaching sessions, and other activities designed to provide them with a better understanding of how to put together a research plan that is ambitious yet practical. Broader impacts are also discussed in terms are educational activities, outreach and applications to societal problems.

The workshop, supported by the Division of Chemistry, is entitled, "Chemistry Early Career Investigator Workshop," will be held on March 10-12, 2016 in Arlington, Virginia. This workshop brings together 100 junior faculty from a broad range of institutions and demographics to discuss steps in strategically crafting research ideas, planning educational and outreach activities, and assessing and evaluating project aims.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of the proposed NSF CHE Early Career Investigator workshop was to provide early career chemist with relevant information needed to better assess their research ideas, projects, and plans so as to more effectively compete for grant applications to the NSF CAREER program, other NSF programs and other federal agencies. To help these young investigators a 2-day workshop consisting of presentations from scientist who have received CAREER awards, program officers from the NSF’s division of chemistry and other programs relevant to early-career chemists was held on March 9th and 10th 2016. There were 100 attendees at that workshop 32% were women, 21% identified as underrepresented minorities URMs (7% women). They majority of the attendees were faculty, 90% with 9% and 1% of the attendees being postdocs and graduate students respectively. The feedback received was overwhelmingly positive, with many attendees expressing an enhanced understanding of the grant submission process and agency expectations, based on post-conference surveys. Overall, attendees expressed an increase confidence about the process.

According to the Division of Chemistry (CHE) in fiscal year 2016, the success rate for the CAREER program was 23%. Twenty, or approximately 20% of the workshop attendees submitted CAREER proposals to CHE in 2016. Of those who did not receive an award, 14 resubmitted in 2017. In 2016, the success rate of these workshop attendees was 25% within CHE. Of the 5 awardees in this group one is a woman and one is an URM.There were 17 attendees that submitted for the first time in 2017. There were 191 scientists that applied for the workshop but were not selected. Of those, 33 submitted to the CAREER program with a success rate of 18%. Two of the six awardees were women, none were URMs.  So overall the workshop attendees applied for more CAREER awards (20% in 2016 and 23% in 17), than those who were not selected for the workshop, (17% in 2016 and 15% in 2017). Furthermore, based on survey result many of the attendee’s reported success in obtaining other grants both federal and non-federal. Unfortunately, we cannot compare these number to those outside the control group. Thus, the workshop has a positive impact on the targeted populations.

 

Lastly, additional travel support was provided to two female attendees that travelled infant children with them to help cover the extra caregiver cost. This was an option offered to the applicants and was critical in enabling these women to attend. The remaining funds from the 2016 workshop were used to support 4 URM faculty’s attendance at the 2017 workshop. This allowed that group to increase the number of faculty whom they could support, further enhancing the diversity of the attendees.
